description: A catastrophic earthquake has left Tokyo, and most of the Earth for that matter, under the sea. Aika is a salvager who retrieves various remains from the watery ruins. When Aika accepts the dangerous mission of locating and obtaining the mysterious Lagu, she discovers that she's not the only one after it.

tags.name: Nudity
tags.description: Features a character wearing no clothing or exposing intimate body parts.

tags.name: Bisexual
tags.description: Features a character who is romantically or sexually attracted to people of more than one sex or gender.

tags.name: Sadism
tags.description: Prominently features characters deriving pleasure, especially sexual gratification, from inflicting pain, suffering, or humiliation on others.

tags.name: Espionage
tags.description: Prominently features characters infiltrating an organization in order to steal sensitive information.

tags.name: Slapstick
tags.description: Prominently features comedy based on deliberately clumsy actions or embarrassing events.

tags.name: Female Protagonist
tags.description: Main character is female.

tags.name: Crossdressing
tags.description: Prominently features a character dressing up as the opposite sex.

tags.name: Henshin
tags.description: Prominently features character or costume transformations which often grant special abilities.

tags.name: Bondage
tags.description: Features BDSM, with or without the use of accessories.

tags.name: Primarily Female Cast
tags.description: Main cast is mostly composed of female characters.

tags.name: Primarily Adult Cast
tags.description: Main cast is mostly composed of characters above a high school age.

tags.name: Post-Apocalyptic
tags.description: Partly or completely set in a world or civilization after a global disaster.

tags.name: Guns
tags.description: Prominently features the use of guns in combat.

tags.name: Female Harem
tags.description: Main cast features the protagonist plus several female characters who are romantically interested in them.

tags.name: Body Horror
tags.description: Features characters who undergo horrific transformations or disfigurement, often to their own detriment.

tags.name: Tanks
tags.description: Prominently features the use of tanks or other armoured vehicles.

tags.name: Tanned Skin
tags.description: Prominently features characters with tanned skin.

tags.name: Heterosexual
tags.description: Prominently features a romance between a man and a woman, not inherently sexual.

tags.name: Aviation
tags.description: Regarding the flying or operation of aircraft.

tags.name: Incest
tags.description: Features sexual or romantic relations between characters who are related by blood.

tags.name: Ships
tags.description: Prominently features the use of sea-based transportation vessels.

tags.name: Urban
tags.description: Partly or completely set in a city.

tags.name: Cars
tags.description: Centers around the use of automotive vehicles.

tags.name: Work
tags.description: Centers around the activities of a certain occupation.

tags.name: Environmental
tags.description: Concern with the state of the natural world and how humans interact with it.

name.native: リエ ペトリヤコワ

node.description:
[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/%E4%BC%8A%E6%9D%B1%E5%B2%B3%E5%BD%A6) | [Wiki (en)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Takehiko_It%C5%8D)

Takehiko Itou, born in Kitami, Hokkaido Prefecture, Japan, is an illustrator and mangaka best known for his work on [Outlaw Star](https://anilist.co/anime/400/). He was also the primary creative mind behind [Angel Links](https://anilist.co/anime/1226/), the [Future Retro Hero Story](https://anilist.co/manga/33718/) manga, and other works of fiction set in the Toward Stars universe. He also developed the original concept for [NG Knight Ramune & 40](https://anilist.co/anime/2084/).

(Source: Anidb)

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/masaakiyuasa)

An acclaimed anime director known for his wild, freeform style. 

After graduating from the Kyushu Sangyo University's Faculty of Arts in 1987 he joined studio [Ajia-do](https://anilist.co/studio/30/Ajiado), initially as in-betweener but rapidly moving to key animation. 

In the first part of his career Yuasa established himself as an idiosyncratic creator while working on several child friendly anime, such as [Chibi Maruko-chan](https://anilist.co/anime/951/Chibi-Marukochan/) and [Doraemon](https://anilist.co/anime/2677/Doraemon-Nobitas-Animal-Planet/), but especially on [Crayon Shin-chan](https://anilist.co/anime/966/Shin-Chan/), a project he was involved with for most of the '90s. 

One of his breakthrough roles in this period was his participation on the second part of [The Hakkenden](https://anilist.co/anime/12715/The-Hakkenden-Legend-of-the-Dog-Warriors-Part-2/), working as animation director under [Shinya Oohira](https://anilist.co/staff/103893/Shinya-Oohira)'s direction. This OVA was an important outing of the '90s, uniting many veteran artists and talented newcomers. 

He debuted as director on [Mind Game](https://anilist.co/anime/875/Mind-Game/), an abstract piece combining animation and live-action footage, winning the 2004 Japan Media Arts Festival (overcoming even Hayao Miyazaki's [Howl's Moving Castle](https://anilist.co/anime/431/Howls-Moving-Castle/)), and earning [Yoshiyuki Tomino](https://anilist.co/staff/97337/Yoshiyuki-Tomino)'s praise, who acted as the chief judge. After Mind Game Yuasa spent several years at [MADHOUSE](https://anilist.co/studio/11/MADHOUSE) working on various projects. In 2013, he founded [Science SARU](https://anilist.co/studio/6145/Science-SARU) alongside his close affiliate [Eun-Yeong Choi](https://anilist.co/staff/115088/EunYeong-Choi).

On March 25, 2020 it was announced Yuasa stepped down as the CEO of Science SARU. He would work there as director until the completion of his latest Movie, [Inu-Oh](https://anilist.co/anime/109928/InuOh/), and would later cease any affiliation with the studio.

On February 17, 2025 it was announced that Yuasa would launch of his own animation studio, ame pippin. Their debut project would be the film [Daisy's Life](https://anilist.co/anime/190574/Hinagiku-no-Jinsei/).

[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/森山雄治) | [Wiki (en)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Yuji_Moriyama) | [Twitter](https://twitter.com/i/user/77356964)

Yuuji Moriyama is a director, animator and character designer.

Moriyama started helping out with in-between animation when he was a student at Kanto Daiichi High School. After graduating from high school, he joined Studio Musashi, which was recruiting staff through newspaper ads. His first work as an official in-betweener was for [Wakusei Robo Danguard Ace](https://anilist.co/anime/1986/). He then moved to Studio Cockpit, where he worked on [Galaxy Express 999](https://anilist.co/anime/1491/), before moving on to NeoMedia. There he worked on [Trider G7](https://anilist.co/anime/4536/), [Doraemon](https://anilist.co/anime/2471/), and [Belle and Sebastian](https://anilist.co/anime/3836/). With Trider G7, he was promoted from in-between to key animation. He left NeoMedia in 1982 to work as a freelancer, starting with [Combat Mecha Xabungle](https://anilist.co/anime/2254/) and [Makyou Densetsu Acrobunch](https://anilist.co/anime/3880/).

The popular anime [Urusei Yatsura](https://anilist.co/anime/1293/), in which he participated from the same year, was Moriyama's breakthrough work. With this series, he made his debut as an animation director and storyboard artist, and was in charge of the opening animation for the first time, joining a group of popular animators overnight. Chief director [Mamoru Oshii](https://anilist.co/staff/99097/), who was responsible for Urusei Yatsura, expected him to become a partner, so Moriyama tried his hand at manga as well by illustrating a manga written by Oshii that was serialized in the Animage magazine in 1984 called Todo no Tsumari. After the end of Urusei Yatsura, he was selected as a character designer for the later series [Maison Ikkoku](https://anilist.co/anime/1453/), and has since been in charge of character design for many other works. In 1987, he won the 4th Japan Anime Awards in the Animation Director category. After that, he shifted from animating to directing.
After that he participated in many works, mainly Chaos Project , Studio Pierrot , and Studio Hibari and then has seated at Studio Hibari's Lerche. 

Moriyama often works under one of his many pen-names.
Originating from [Studio Deen](https://anilist.co/studio/37/) where he studied under [Atsuko Nakajima](https://anilist.co/staff/102141/).

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/choco_kiku) | [Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/菊地洋子)

Married to [Eiji Suganuma](https://anilist.co/staff/109167/).

_Note: Not to be confused with [Youko Kikuchi (菊地陽子)](https://anilist.co/staff/141535/), different kanji._

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/choco_kiku) | [Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/菊地洋子)

Married to [Eiji Suganuma](https://anilist.co/staff/109167/).

_Note: Not to be confused with [Youko Kikuchi (菊地陽子)](https://anilist.co/staff/141535/), different kanji._

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/choco_kiku) | [Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/菊地洋子)

Married to [Eiji Suganuma](https://anilist.co/staff/109167/).

_Note: Not to be confused with [Youko Kikuchi (菊地陽子)](https://anilist.co/staff/141535/), different kanji._

Best known as the creator of [Project A-Ko](https://anilist.co/anime/212/). He is particularly noted for his work during the ‘80s, going all out in [Urusei Yatsura](https://anilist.co/anime/1293/) and many OVAs and films such as [Outlanders](https://anilist.co/anime/1940/) and [Dirty Pair](https://anilist.co/anime/1796/). He is among the many [Kanada](https://anilist.co/staff/106398/)-influenced animators of the ‘80s, and his work is recognizable from its wide-eyed characters, attention to anatomical detail, and characterful impact frames.

Initially he wanted to be a mangaka, but enrolled in university instead after not being sure if he could make a living - though, he did drop out after a year. During his short lived time there, he was watching [Gundam](https://anilist.co/anime/80/) and had sent a letter to [Yoshiyuki Tomino](https://anilist.co/staff/97337/) with the hopes of joining [Sunrise](https://anilist.co/studio/14/). They weren’t accepting in-betweeners at this time, so a producer of theirs referred him to [Studio Live](https://anilist.co/studio/6460/), which he then joined after passing an entrance test in 1979. There he studied under the studio’s founder, [Toyoo Ashida](https://anilist.co/staff/110953/), and started gaining attention for his work on Urusei Yatsura.

After working at [Studio Deen](https://anilist.co/studio/37/) for a while, he took part in the establishment of Studio Graviton alongside [Hideaki Anno](https://anilist.co/staff/100111/), [Shouichi Masuo](https://anilist.co/staff/133909/) and [Kouji Itou](https://anilist.co/staff/101166/). He then went freelance and worked regularly for [Studio Fantasia](https://anilist.co/studio/24/).

Lately he has shifted more and more towards directing and storyboarding rather than animating himself, often collaborating with his long-time friends [Yuuji Moriyama](https://anilist.co/staff/100658/) and [Noriyasu Yamauchi](https://anilist.co/staff/112903/).
[Website](http://gingami.art.coocan.jp/)

__Skills & Abilities:__ Speaks fluent Japanese

Founder, Owner, and Managing Director of Central Park Media.

Araki Hideki is an animator, animation supervisor and character designer. In recent years he has been working exclusively on 18+ titles, where he also took over as director additionally to his usual work.

[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/高村和宏)

A freelance animator formerly part of [Gainax](https://anilist.co/studio/6/). Debuted on the 14th episode of [Evangelion](https://anilist.co/anime/30/).

_Note: Not to be confused with the other [animator](https://anilist.co/staff/223351/) with the exact same name._

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/fujimari_617) | [Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/藤田まり子)

A Japanese animator and designer.
He was originally part of Studio Live, but in 1995 switched over to Studio Fantasia.
He was originally part of Studio Live, but in 1995 switched over to Studio Fantasia.
Tsutomu Miyazawa is an animator, storyboard artist, character and mechanical designer formerly affiliated with [Studio Kikan](https://anilist.co/studio/256/).

Affiliated with [J.C. Staff](https://anilist.co/studio/7/).

Sakurabi made his directional debut with [Gunparade March](https://anilist.co/anime/266/). He is a fan of simple and refreshing love stories. As a director he's known for modifying original stories a lot, which has brought him substantial amounts of critique. He is quite infamous for his work as the director of the [Tsukihime](https://anilist.co/anime/169/) adaptation, with most fans disapproving of his changes from the original visual novel.

Amongst his most notable directorial works are [Yomigaeru Sora: Rescue Wings](https://anilist.co/anime/798/) and [Flying Witch](https://anilist.co/anime/21284/).

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/sakouyukie) | [Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/%E4%BD%90%E5%85%89%E5%B9%B8%E6%81%B5)

Yukie Sakou is an animator and character designer.
He was originally part of Studio Live, but in 1995 switched over to Studio Fantasia.

Best known as the creator of [Project A-Ko](https://anilist.co/anime/212/). He is particularly noted for his work during the ‘80s, going all out in [Urusei Yatsura](https://anilist.co/anime/1293/) and many OVAs and films such as [Outlanders](https://anilist.co/anime/1940/) and [Dirty Pair](https://anilist.co/anime/1796/). He is among the many [Kanada](https://anilist.co/staff/106398/)-influenced animators of the ‘80s, and his work is recognizable from its wide-eyed characters, attention to anatomical detail, and characterful impact frames.

Initially he wanted to be a mangaka, but enrolled in university instead after not being sure if he could make a living - though, he did drop out after a year. During his short lived time there, he was watching [Gundam](https://anilist.co/anime/80/) and had sent a letter to [Yoshiyuki Tomino](https://anilist.co/staff/97337/) with the hopes of joining [Sunrise](https://anilist.co/studio/14/). They weren’t accepting in-betweeners at this time, so a producer of theirs referred him to [Studio Live](https://anilist.co/studio/6460/), which he then joined after passing an entrance test in 1979. There he studied under the studio’s founder, [Toyoo Ashida](https://anilist.co/staff/110953/), and started gaining attention for his work on Urusei Yatsura.

After working at [Studio Deen](https://anilist.co/studio/37/) for a while, he took part in the establishment of Studio Graviton alongside [Hideaki Anno](https://anilist.co/staff/100111/), [Shouichi Masuo](https://anilist.co/staff/133909/) and [Kouji Itou](https://anilist.co/staff/101166/). He then went freelance and worked regularly for [Studio Fantasia](https://anilist.co/studio/24/).

Lately he has shifted more and more towards directing and storyboarding rather than animating himself, often collaborating with his long-time friends [Yuuji Moriyama](https://anilist.co/staff/100658/) and [Noriyasu Yamauchi](https://anilist.co/staff/112903/).
Retired as an animator in the late '90s, and has since mainly focused on storyboarding.
He was originally part of Studio Live, but in 1995 switched over to Studio Fantasia.
